reviewText: Blazblue has been a personal favorite of the fighting game genre. I can say without a doubt this has been one of the best versions of the games. Learning the mechanics for each character can take some serious work, especially for the challenge mode. But its the best way to understand how to combo with each character. But the balance for each character and their abilities have been adjusted for each character to a much better degree than the previous titles. Even the story mode has a simple ark to follow rather than going through 20 individual stories like with Calamity Trigger or Continuum Shift. Not to mention trying to get 100% through the true, bad, and gag endings. But the gag scenes are all their for each character and has fit in well for the same humor to follow. The extra modes in this title no doubt will give a few newbies a rage run given the extended difficulty. But even under the fustration of learning all the Distoration Finishes and Astral Heat finishings, the characters are still strong and makes one want to dive deeper into mastering the characters fully. I will give one warning, the story will still confuse some that have not seen or played through the others since some things may not make sense. Even then, its still a great story to follow up with and the fighting is just as intense. But with all the characters having their mechnical features, Bullet is a really tough one to take up. Not just her special mechnic of heat drives and dives seems pretty weak. Not to mention she does not have the best moves to open up to in combat compared to those that are faster and have range attacks. So fair warning if using her in anything... and I know there might be someone that knows how to use her better than me, but this is just a simple perspective and oberservation given the time I have played this game. In terms of time for the game, if you want to get through everything and unlock all thats possible, following up with Abyss Mode to get the most currency out of the game... its most likely to be 40-50 hours of game time for a first time run. Especially if you want to get through the hard modes and higher levels. Pratice will make perfect.Im excited to see this not just come to Steam, but now I can take Makoto Nanaya anywhere and crush all that stand before her! Sorry, I just love that character for her personality and kick buutt power! Moving on, the music continues to hold strong for not just the characters themes: but for the background themes too. Making the matches more exciting to push ahead and show everything one has for that victory. Even having the old levels and music from the previous games to be bought with the in game currency. Even having the famous Teach me Miss Litichi sceens are back for all the history and understanding the Blazblue world, and look it up for a good laugh. Overall, this game easily earns a 8/10. Worth buying anytime and expore the insane combos and story between all the characters.

reviewText:
whoa a good blazblue game

the plot is still stupid as usual, and if you have lots of free time, you're gonna eat it all up. if you missed out on the past games, but care about this convoluted mess of a story, there's a recap. you arent even done here with the story tho since we have a new BlazBlue game coming, annnd the side materials like Bloodedge Experience, XBlaze, etc.

= Pros =
+  Fast-paced gameplay.
+ Great soundtrack. You can also unlock the original tracks, and use the over the remixes in player matches, which, in my opinion, is still so much better.
+ Really good 2D sprites.
+ For casual players, there are many offline modes. Here for the lore? Play Story Mode, and watch Teach Me! Miss Litchi. Just here for the gameplay, but don't wanna play online? Score Attack. Arcade. Abyss.
+ And with those many offline modes above, you'll be spending lots of time offline too, beating and unlocking everything. There are in-game currency, and you can use it to buy new palettes, Unlimited versions, illustrations, old BGM, and more!
+ Accessible to beginners. There's Stylish Mode if you just want to mash your ways offline, but I discourage you from using it online. Tutorial Mode is super helpful, and Challenge Mode will teach you a few combos.
+ A large cast. You'll find a character you like to play sooner or later.
+ If you're a vanilla CP player, and wanna relive the glory of Kokonoe, here you go. You can play vanilla CP mode offline.
+ A LOT MORE BALANCED THAN CS. THANK GOD RACHEL ISN'T LOW-TIER ANYMORE.

= Cons =
Honestly really tried to find flaws, but... they're just so tiny compared to the pros.

- It's super accessible, sure, but mastering everything is difficult. Might be a pro, since that means you'll be investing more time gitting gud at this game.
- Everything might seem intimidating to beginners at first.
- Network Mode is... a bit laggy. Better than CS, but if you live far, there's gonna be input lag.  (Wiring your internet might fix this, but if you don't have a network cable...)
- Searching for lobbies or ranked matches are regionlocked. As a Southeast Asian player, I rarely find matches online.
- Most players I've encountered aren't really aware they're NOT supposed to skip intros. Man, fighting 5 Ragnas in a row on ranked--THAT ALSO SKIP INTROS--sure was fuuuuuuuuuuuunnnnn.

TL;DR it's a good fighting game for both casuals and competitive players. online might be difficult if you're in a certain region, but you'll eventually find people to play with. its story mode is pretty much a visual novel on its own. and of course, lots of waifus and husbandos...

reviewText:
I love me some Guilty Gear, but I haven't had a current generation console since the PS2, so I've been wanting to play BlazBlue for quite some time, and now that I finally have, I can say it took some getting used to.  Combos are easier in this game than they are in Guilty Gear, so that's a plus.  But to help reduce the execution barrier for newcomers, BlazBlue introduced stylish mode, which I still don't fully understand yet as I'm a technical player and prefer to use technical mode for that reason, but one of my friends who's very new to fighting games, is able to fight me on pretty even footing with stylish mode.  Given, I'm still pretty new to this game and still have a lot of growing to do in my skill level, but it's the first time I've seen him not suck, and actually have fun playing a fighting game, so I guess that makes BlazBlue the most approachable fighting game I've seen yet (give or take Evil Zone on the PlayStation or Super Smash Bros.).

The graphics are nice, and the 2D sprites are good, but I feel like they need a little more anti-aliasing to smooth out the outlines a bit.  Still, it's a great looking game and it actually has a lot of special VS intros between the characters, like many older fighting games had, most notably Capcom VS SNK 2.  I missed seeing those and I'm really glad BlazBlue's keeping that tradition alive instead of just using the same intro animations over and over regardless of whether or not your characters have a direct story-line beef with each other.  The game's mechanics are solid, yet smooth as well, and there's a huge variety in play styles among the massive cast of characters.  If you like anime fighting games or Arcsys fighting games, you're not going to want to miss this one.

Character specific VS intros.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: Even thoug my playime may be on the short side, I played this game on PS4
and simply bought it again to support the series.

The definitve Chronpantasma experience, featuring all the DLC released for consoles in one package.

Out of the many figting games on PC, Blazblue is one of te most accessible games out there. It features extensive tutorials on overall gameplay mechanics, followed by character specific tutorials and tactical tips. The challenge mode also offers insight into practical combos for each character to use. The game also features stylish mode, where even the most casual players can enoy seing incredible combos and effects.

Graphically, the game has gorgeous character sprites mixed with full 3D backgrounds. Due to the game being anime style, the art aesthetic will be either hit or miss: if you greatly dislike anime art style, this could be a deal breaker.

Blazblue series is characterized by a varied cast, each character having a unique gameplay mechanic. While some characters are weaker than others, there as an alright sense of balance. Due to characters having different gameplay mechanics, Blazblue is much harder to balance than Mortal Kombat X for example. While these differences may go unnoticed by new players, on competative level, you can clearly see certaiin characters being superior to others.

Some of the characters will be hit-or-miss due to their designs, more so than in other games.

A lot of people complain that the story is generally reading through walls of text, which is true since tis is a visual novel. Honestly though, most fighting games dont even bother having a story. If you are sceptical about te story, ust give it a chance, as the good story telling is what set original Blazblue:Calamity Trigger game apart from the many 2D fighting games. But at te end of the day, if you still dislike it, you can simply use the skip function and breeze through it,

The online experience on the PC port was disappointing to say te least. Latency issues, frequent disconnects and random frame rate drops are all present here. Whike you can find fixes for some of te issues here on the forums, its disappointing that the publisher didn't adress those issues. In my opinion, this is the main deal breaker, as you want to play online wit oter people after you have played through the various single-player game modes.

TL;DR: A solid fighting game, suitable for newcomers to figting games and veterans alike. Unique characters each with their own gameplay mechanics, rendered in glorious sprites. A robust storymode suffering from wall-of-text syndrome, and a grat offering of other singlepayer modes. The main issue with the port is the spotty online functionality.

This game is a better optimized than Continuum Shift Extend. In CSE, while I had perfect FPS in a match, the Menus and Character Select were really slow for some reason, 30-40 FPS at times. Also, Astral Finishes would constantly send the game down to 30 FPS. Chronophantasma only dips when loading a match for only 1/4 of a second. This is from playing on a laptop with integrated graphics. Well done Arc on that.

Sound:
As expected of an Arc figther, the soundtrack is amazing. Some of the remix tracks are a little hit and miss, but over all great quality music. Sadly, sound test is completely absent. The bonus Soundtrack is also a little underwhelming. It only brings tracks unique to Extend content for the most part.

Story:
Quite extensive this go around. Not only do you have the main story and gag reels but you also get abriged versions of the previous games, a short but enjoyable Remix Heart, a Library section to look up anything pertaining to the setting and characters, new gag reels, and more.

Characters:
As to be expected, the new additions are just as interesting as the returning cast. Each designed around unique gameplay styles.

Modes:
A large selection of modes to spend your time in. The training modes are quite extensive with a good tutorial, combo challenge modes, as well as training mode. Other modes include: Arcade, Score Attack, Unlimited Mars (still as insane as ever), a redesigned Abyss mode, and Highlander if you complete the main story. One quick note on Abyss mode, this time around, you will not lose your hard earned currency if you don't make it through the entire run. While I did like the risk in the previous Abyss mode of CSE, I am fine with this change.

Online:
The netcode works pretty good for most of my experiences. Most of my matches have performed flawlessly with hardly/no delay. Your milage may vary. As for waiting to find matches, it has range for me from approx 5 minute wait to as short as a few seconds of entering into ranked pool.

Extras:
You can now save Local Replays from VS Mode!!! The gallery mode is mostly the same as CSE, but there is a whole lot more to unlock this go around. However, once again, the complete lack of Sound Test can really hurt for many people (myself included).

Overall, this is a solid port thats very fairly priced (especially if you already have previous games for the discount).

reviewText:
UPDATED ON 18 MARCH

Well well well... Look what we have here: Another installment of one of my most favorite franchises on steam! Hey ArcSys/H2, thank you for this.
Okay, let's see how good this one is. WARNING: This is going to be long! Also, BOSS FIGHT SPOILERS!

Before we begin, I just want to say this game REALLY reminded me of Guilty Gear Xrd -SIGN- at first; because of Guilty Gear characters' icons for your profile, nearly similar design for library section, Izayoi's dash move which is incredibly similar to I-No's dash from GGXRD and the overdrive mechanic which activates by pressing all 4 attack buttons together (sounds familiar, huh?).

First things first, unlike some other fighting games that sacrifice offline modes (you know which ones I mean), this game has a lot of single player content. Story mode consists of the main story and continues from where Continuum Shift was ended; along with extend verion's story, anthology which explains the story of previous titles in a not expectable way, another ((Teach Me Miss Litchi!)) and a storyline named Remix Heart which I tried it recently and has a very... um... weird story. You'll understand what I mean when you play it. Then there is arcade mode, versus, abyss mode (some kind of survival mode), unlimited mars mode and score attack mode. So, if you want to play this offline because of reasons (like myself), you're going to be entertained for a long time.

And now, the gameplay! well... the gameplay has changed a bit compared to the last game. First, some of the mechanics are changed. For example, Ragna's Blood Kain move is removed and it's effects are replaced with his overdrive (Blood Kain IDEA). The second is the overdrive that I mentioned before. Overdrive can enhance and increase the damage of your attacks but it only lasts for a limited time and it's gauge needs to be recharged after use. Also, during overdrive, time counter will freeze so it can be used to your advantage. And one more thing, if you use burst, you cannot use overdrive and vice versa; Because the gauge for both of them are the same.

And now we get to other aspects (I usually don't care about graphics; I just see if gameplay can hook me in). Thank god because this game doesn't have the level up thing which was in the last game. Sure, it was nice at first but it got very frustrating after some time. Also, I have to mention this game has a very nice and polished port and there's a high chance you can get it to run even on older PCs. Now about the final boss (Takemizukachi if I'm not mistaken). This REALLY reminded me of Guilty Gear Isuka somehow (I really don't know why); and it was brilliantly BAD! Why? It changed positions 5 TIMES IN A ROW so I was constantly running from side to side! How I'm supposed to enjoy fighting it this way?

PROS:
- Optimized for PC. You can play this game without problems
- Great story mode (Like always)
- Great offline/single player content
- Fast and challenging gameplay
- Very nice tutorial mode
- Music remixes are mostly done well
- GREAT English voice acting

CONS:
- Final boss.
- Some of the musics are not very good and you probably finish the match before hearing their best parts (This happened for me against Iron Tager).
- There's a glitch in the game that makes it to display incorrectly and out of bounds. This only happens if you close the steam client's window shortly before game launches and is temporary.
- IS THERE ANY POSSIBLE WAY TO BEAT UNLIMITED MARS MODE?!
- Other problems that I wasn't able to spot yet...

VERDICT:
You like fighting games? You like great story modes? You want a learn fast, difficult to master gameplay? You want enough single player content?
If your answer is YES, then buy this game and you will not be disappointed!

Now if you excuse me, I'm going to play it some more... Oh, and I maybe update this later...

reviewText:
A Dated game but still worth a look

I'm not the best fighting game player and over the years Arcsys managed to attract me to Blazblue with its interesting characters, its anime like artstyle and engrosingly deep character back stories. So even if you are not the best at the stick if you are looking for intregue in a story rich universe you might give it a bash. However there are a few short comings in this age.

The Mixed bag:

It is a console port so some limitations are expected. The problem is when you no longer adhere to the once console limits of 1080p and cross into the realm of 1440p, 4k, ultrawide, 100hz+ refresh rates you will be disappointed to find that the game is upscaled from 720p60fps. It looks very dated for more reasons than just this fact.

The game uses beaulifully and detailed sprite animations and the effort is clearly visiable as each character feel. That said it was still designed with a low res in mind with no high detailed models and down sampling. The other thing to take note of is that Guilty Gear Xrd was released not too long ago sporting full poly models making even 1080p look managable and frankly giving the characters more depth.

The story mode will be the meat for those not into the competitive scene yet unlike BB CS it does not contrain the previous story modes. You will have to get both Continuum Shift and Chronophantasma if you want to see where we are and how we got to this point.

Character design and backstory really shines as certain characters will have different face off chatter to the norm under cerstain conditions. This adds to the feel that the characters know each other and has a deeper connection.

If you can forgive the lack of catering to newer specced PCs but want more of the BB universe or just a fighting game with a deep story mode, then Chronophantasma is worth a look.

reviewText:
You know who's basically the leading company on fighting games? Arc System Works, with the Blazblue series and the Guilty Gear series, they own two of the few great fighting games there are.

Love Combos? Love action packed games? Love getting your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• kicked by people online? This is the game for you.

Not much of a fighting guy, but enjoy it casually? Don't worry, the more deeper we go into the Blazblue series the more it becomes a Visual Novel. The game has such a great story, with plot twists here and there. Even though it's the third game in the story, it managed to fill you in if you've missed out on the previous games.

Pros?:

- Action Packed Story.

- Fun fighting casually and competitive

- Has a great netcode if you ever manage to find someone online

- Celica A. Mercury, probably the best character ever to be added into a franchise.

- No pay for DLC, it's all in the game, Kokonoe as well!

- Kokonoe has probably been the character everyone wanted implemented into the game, and here she is!

Cons?:

- Even if it has a great netcode, it still sort of feels unplayable when playing online with someone distant, say continents apart.

- If you were an avid player of the originals, movesets were changed, rather, added on, and that definitely makes it a bit harder to relearn all the mechanics

- Not being able to play with console players, this sucks because the online community here is almost never on.

TL;DR:

- The game's great, and if you enjoy fighting games, but don't want it to really interrupt the story it has that, and then there's a whole bunch of fighting modes for you to play.

- Kokonoe Mercury and Celica A. Mercury

- Tsubaki's costume color changed, but that's alright.

- Noel got a new costume and it looks nice.

The story is great and if you've played Calamity Trigger and Continuum Shift before, you would have noticed that the story is much more straightforward now. No more purposely dying for a new route and no need to purposely do distortion drives or something. The normal and joke routes are very obvious and are very entertaining to watch. This is the first time I can feel myself loving the characters in the Blazblue series aside from liking Ragna beating the crap out of everyone. I began respecting Kagura although he can be a jerk. I liked how Noel has evolved from a wimp into, somewhat stronger girl. I liked how Jin could finally stop being a 100% jerk like in CT and CS, though he's still a jerk... And yeah, I actually liked it when Kagura made a stand and I love how all of the villains can be top level jerks to the point where I hate all of them, which is good because that's how villains should be. I'd recommend this game to casuals easily because not only it's a serious fighting game, you can get yourself into story mode and get like, I don't know, I have 30 hours of gameplay already?

reviewText:
Well, I'm pretty embarrassed while writing this review because I don't know if I would recommend this game or not.
Let's put it this way: if you're fan of Japanese visual novels/anime, then you would still be as pleased as with the previous BlazBlue games. The story is not quite as good as CT or CS but it is decent enough to keep you interested until the end.
The game offers a lot of single player modes like Arcade, Abyss, Score Attack or the fight against a special boss (I won't spoil what it is) and there are many reports of it having a pretty good netcode for online play. And finally, the game doesn't seem to have many major issues running on PC.

Now... the bad news:
- This is just a PC port of the PS3 version which keeps the arcade proportions. Sprites and menus are set to 720p and look extremely ugly and pixelated on higher resolutions. Compatibility sits therefore very uncomfortably between gaming PCs who are too advanced to display it properly and toasters who can't display it at all. It is still playable but... yuck.
- The gameplay. Ok, I know, this is a matter of taste, you either like air-dashers or not blahblah, but I cannot help but find that the BB series has taken a path made of an increasing number of complicated mechanics which are too much for many gamers' minds to take a hold of: Rapid Cancel, Crush Trigger, Counter Assault, Burst, Overdrive, Barrier Block, Instant Block... You can clearly see this game was made in a time when SF4 was still a thing and adding gimmicks to escape or invert any situation was still seen as cool. They know very well they screwed up and that's why they added Stylish mode since CS, which is in my eyes just an acknowledgement of failure in creating an accessible game.
As for the game tutorials, while they are better than CSE ones (particularly the character tutorials) they sadly still look as they were written by fighting game nerds so deeply immersed in their own vocabulary that they aren't aware of the existence of an outside world. Reading an online guide is far less tedious and more practical than going through this.

So I would say, if you're interested in good anime-styled single player content, this can be the game for you. If you happen to be part of the very specific niche who likes technical air-dashers and wanna play online with other enthousiasts of the genre... then you probably already own this game and don't need my advice.
But if you wanna get into fighting other people online and offline, be aware that this game may not be a very welcoming and forgiving experience. The player base is extremely small (I can never find more than 10-15 people in online lobbies a week after launch) and there's a high chance your opponent will be a BB veteran with no compassion for newbies.

I'll give a negative review because it has so many good reviews it won't be counted anyway, and to get downvoted as much as possible.

reviewText:
It will be a review made by complete n00b in fighting games. I've warned you.

I had a little romance with games like Tekken, Mortal Combat or King of Fighters, but as I said it was just a romance. If we are talking about BlazBlue franchise, then I can clearly tell, that I'm in love.
Gaming Warlocks from Arc System certainly knows how to make good games. They even know how to make sequels far greater than previous games! That's just incredible!

It's hard for me to tell what changed between Continuum Shift and ChronoPhantasma in terms of gameplay (aside from removing Golden Break Bursts, Guard Primers, quicken gameplay a bit, adding Overdrive and replacing Guard Crush with Crush Trigger), but what I'm certain is fact, that combos and special attacks are easier to preform than before. I'm not sure if It's just me becoming pro or something really changed, but mentioning it won't hurt.

AI is finally intelligent and in every mode (except most fights in story mode) it's giving a little chalange to battle them. At least if you are n00b like me.

Now it's time for PLOT! <insert image with boobs here>
Toshimichi Mori serve us again extremly deep, multi-threaded history with TONS of hard to understand things, termology that normally wouldn't had any sense etc. but if you enjoyed story so far, then you will be in heaven. Now story isn't presented from the perspective of a certain character, so you don't need to complete history by fighting as character you don't like...
At least not that much as in previous games. (BTW. screw you Hakumen!)
Plot is very enjoyable if you like this kind of stories, but there is one controversial thing about, how it is presented. Most people is probably accustomed to a little bit of story, then text, then story, then again fight and so on. ChronoPhantasma have a diffrent proportions from previous games. There is A LOT of text (with kind of funny animations with sprites reminding me of a certain indie game), then a short fight with character being main character at the moment, then again a WALL of text, then again short fight, short cutscene and again TEXT.
Please, don't misunderstand me. I've enjoyed this story much more than before and for me this proportions made story much more captivating than in CT and CS, but for many people it will be one of the cons of this game.

Ok. Are you still reading? Yes? Oh. I must say, I'm impressed by your endurance! Stay a bit more and there will be your awaited end. Not your end of course.

So, where I left? Oh right! Soundtrack. I have a mixed feelings about it. Most songs from previous games was remade and/or remixed and sometimes they are a lot better than original (e.g Sword of Doom II or Bullet Dance II) but there are songs that is kind of worse than before (e.g Awakening a Chaos II or Xmatic II). Then again, don't misunderstand me. These which for me is worse than original, isn't bad. Just... they aren't fitting my taste anymore. Still, Daisuke Ishiwatari done a great job.

Visuals are pretty as always and still they have this old school arcade feeling. In my opinion, green and colorful Ikaruga gave designers a great range for making stages even more beautiful than before! About characters... I don't think, that something changed between CS and CP, but new Noel's outfit looks great on her.

Now it's time for some cons. Like in Continuum Shift, port from consoles isn't great. You can't find here FullHD support, there few problems with some PC configurations and scalling here is quite bad. But I must tell, I don't really care. Game is great and this port is still better than that of Arkham Knight (lol). If you like fighting games and deep story, then hurry up and buy it!

K'ay. Now we are waiting another 2 or more years for continuation. Eh... Whatever. Gotta go to kick Jin's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for calling my favorite character a trash.
Oh. Did I mentioned that this game ends with big and fatty cliffhanger? :>

reviewText:
Note: This is from my blog, where I included some images and such

Considering this is a fighting game, obviously the first thing to talk about is the controls and responsiveness... and while I've dabbled with fighting games from time to time, there are some universal concepts and commands that comes with these games: up to jump, down to duck, double forward to dash, and various buttons for punches and kicks.. Still I was going into this game blind, having last played the previous BlazBlue title (Continuum Shift Extend) in February of last year, so my skills were rather rusty. Thankfully, my best character was still on the roaster (That being Taokaka) and I managed to blunder my way through several battles in Arcade mode on the games default settings, which is more of a testament to the games controls being very responsive, and with 'practice' one could easily manhandle the game on it's default settings.

So onto how does the game looks... well it looks gorgeous. As a 2D fighter, the amount of detail a game has in the background is plus without it being a distraction. The characters themselves are all rather colorful, if some of the human female characters look rather impractical with attire and proportions. But that's pretty standard with fighting games, and also one of the best things about them. Anyway as you can see, everything is laid out in a traditional format, with the Health Bars at the top and the 'power meters' down at the bottom of the screen.

Onto the sound, and one of the great things about the BlazBlue series is the voice acting is very decent (if at times a bit repetitive, but I'm one to talk), the sound effects are solid with the impact they deliver. Then there is the music, which like a lot of songs for Anime adventure series, have a way of sounding epic and grand while not distracting the player. It blends in perfectly to the background, you know its there, you hear it, but it isn't drawing your attention away from the task at hand, which is playing the game and hoping for a win.

The game has a roster of 28 characters, so there is a lot of replay value for wanting to go through the story and arcade modes to see and unlock everything. Old favorites like Carl Clover, Noel Vermillion,and Bang Shishigami are back, plus new comers like Bullet, Azarel and Amane Nishiki help bring new challenges.

There is a score attack, online play and other secondary features that help keep this game at the forefront of 2D fighters on the PC until the next BlazBlue port comes around in a couple of years for Central Fiction

My recommendation: For $29.99 the price is pretty reasonable, because you are getting the complete game with all the DLC at once shot. So the value is there if you're looking for a 2D-Fighter from a 'franchise' for your PC collection.

reviewText:
Amazing game! I can't believe that I slept on this fighter for years. A game of this caliber should never over shadowed by other fighters such as MKX(not saying that mortal kombat isn't a good fighter but NRS needs to do better!). Ok, I'm not into the whole storyline which is cringe worthy IMO. However, the gameplay is amazing. Imagine MVC2/UMVC3 without the Marvel comics license and the silly assist spamming. Well, there are characters in this game that have assist-like (or puppet master/summoner) abilities but anyways its a 1v1 fighter at its best.

Plenty of different modes including a full visual/audio storyline and arcade mode for casuals and for new people to the series ONE OF THE BEST IN-GAME TUTORIAL MODES THAT I'VE SEEN IN ANY FIGHTING GAME PERIOD! Many companies could learn from Arc System when it comes to the Tutorial mode because it teaches each and everything you need to know about the character you want to play.

Speaking of characters, again BBCPEX has a great amount of variety. You have zoning characters, rush down characters, summoners, all-arounds, grapplers, and even trap based characters. There is literally a character for all styles (Currently play Azreal and the Wolf dude).

What I don't like is the lack of players in the network mode finding a match in ranking is next to impossible at times which again WHY ALL PC FIGHTING GAMES SHOULD HAVE CROSS-PLAY CONSOLE PLAYERS. Granted that the BBCPEX community is very small when compared to the SF and MKX which it make it much more important for Arc System to take heeve to what Capcom and Iron Galaxy did with Cross-play. Sadly, in a few months, the new version of this game will drop on consoles which this version came out 3 years ago. Hopefully, they won't take as long to give us PC people that version with in a timely manner. However, we the PC community dictate that by buying this game!

so, is this game worth buying? Yes it is by a large margin!
